bestBHT.bht: Ceasing not, Paul continually gives thanks and remembers the Ephesians in his prayers, acknowledging their faith and love as gifts from God. Although physically distant, Paul prays for their advancement in knowledge and grace, seeking their welfare even in his absence. This gratefulness is a characteristic of Paul's letters, demonstrating the significance of thanksgiving and petition in his prayer life. Through his unwavering intercession, Paul exhibits both his deep care for the Ephesians and his desire to inspire them to embrace these spiritual practices.

Henry Alford: cease not giving thanks for you, making mention of you in my (ordinary, see Rom. i. 9 note) prayers;
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: oldest manuscripts. Then the translation may be as English Version
Albert Barnes: In the prosperity of the church at Ephesus he could not but feel the deepest interest, and their welfare he never forgot.
Paul was far distant from them, and expected to see them no more. But he had faith in prayer, and he sought that they might advance in knowledge and in grace.
What was the particular subject of his prayers, he mentions in the following verses.
Marvin Vincent: Making mention, etc. As I make mention. The same expression occurs Romans 1:9; Philippians 1:4; Philippians 1:4.
John Calvin: It was necessary that the Ephesians should understand that they had entered upon the proper course.
But it was equally necessary that they should not turn aside to any new scheme of doctrine, or become indifferent about proceeding farther.
Whatever, then, may be the height of our attainments, let them be always accompanied by the desire of something higher.
Philip Schaff: ‘As one giving thanks I cease not.’
The Apostle almost invariably begins his Epistles with thanksgiving, which befits the privileged condition of Christians.
'No thanksgiving without petition, so long as perfection and completion are not yet there’ (Stier).
Archibald T. Robertson: I do not cease (ου παυομα). Singular present middle, while in Colossians 1:9 Paul uses the plural (literary, or including Timothy), ου παυομεθα.
John Gill: On account of their faith and love; which were gifts of grace bestowed upon them, and not the produce of their own free will and power; and therefore thanks are given to God for them.
Which shows the apostle to be a praying person, and that he was constant at the throne of grace, where he prayed for others as well as for himself.
To testify his great affection for them, but also to excite them, by his example, to the practice of those duties themselves.
John Wesley: I cease not — In all my solemn addresses to God.
To give thanks for you, making mention of you in my prayers — So he did of all the churches, Colossians 1:9.

bhtAttempts.bht: Paul expresses his continuous gratitude for the Ephesians, mentioning them in his prayers and thanking God for their faith and love. Despite being physically distant, he fervently prays for their advancement in knowledge and grace. This affectionate concern is evident in Paul's habit of beginning his letters with thanksgiving, demonstrating the importance of gratitude and petition in his prayer life. It is clear that Paul not only desires to testify his love for them but also to inspire them to engage in these practices themselves. Through his unwavering prayers, Paul conveys his genuine interest in the spiritual growth and well-being of the Ephesian church.

Ceasing not, Paul continually gives thanks and remembers the Ephesians in his prayers, acknowledging their faith and love as gifts from God. Although physically distant, Paul prays for their advancement in knowledge and grace, seeking their welfare even in his absence. This gratefulness is a characteristic of Paul's letters, demonstrating the significance of thanksgiving and petition in his prayer life. Through his unwavering intercession, Paul exhibits both his deep care for the Ephesians and his desire to inspire them to embrace these spiritual practices.

Paul expresses continuous gratitude for the Ephesians, mentioning them in his prayers and thanking God for their faith and love. Despite being physically distant, he fervently prays for their advancement in knowledge and grace. This affectionate concern is evident in Paul's habit of beginning his letters with thanksgiving, demonstrating the importance of gratitude and petition in his prayer life. Paul's unwavering prayers convey his genuine interest in the spiritual growth and well-being of the Ephesian church.

Paul's continuous prayers for the Ephesians exemplify his deep gratitude and genuine care for them. He does not cease to thank God for their faith and love, acknowledging these as gifts of grace. Despite the geographical distance between them, Paul remains steadfast in his prayers for their growth in knowledge and grace. This unwavering intercession is a testament to Paul's affectionate concern for the Ephesians and serves as an inspiration for them to prioritize prayer and gratitude in their own lives.

Paul's continuous prayers for the Ephesians showcase his unwavering gratitude and caring nature. He prioritizes thanking God for their faith and love, recognizing these qualities as divine gifts. Despite physical distance, Paul fervently prays for their progress in knowledge and grace. This dedication to intercession reveals his deep affection for the Ephesians and serves as an example for them to prioritize prayer and thanksgiving in their own lives.
